entry.title: Armenia‚Äôs security chief says Yerevan will respond to Baku‚Äôs peace plan ‚Äòsoon‚Äô

media:group.media:title: Armenia‚Äôs security chief says Yerevan will respond to Baku‚Äôs peace plan ‚Äòsoon‚Äô
media:group.media:description:
üìçArmenia will send Azerbaijan a response to a peace proposal recently put forward by Baku ‚Äúsoon,‚Äù Security Council head Armen Grigoryan said. üìçArmenian Foreign Minister Ararat Mirzoyan said he is ‚Äúnot sure‚Äù that Yerevan and Baku can reach a peace agreement by the year‚Äôs end. üìçReceiving a ‚Äúclear political assessment‚Äù from the CSTO, a Russian-led military alliance, remains Armenia‚Äôs priority, Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan said. üìçKarabakh President Arayik Harutyunyan called for ‚Äúinternational guarantees‚Äù to ensure the security of the region‚Äôs Armenian residents. üìçThe prosecutors general of Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Russia met for talks in Moscow.
Credits: Ruptly

entry.title: What does the war of words between Baku and Moscow mean for Karabakh?

media:group.media:title: What does the war of words between Baku and Moscow mean for Karabakh?
media:group.media:description:
In this week‚Äôs episode of Insights with Eric Hacopian, Eric discusses the recent war of words between Baku and Moscow over place names in Karabakh, a resolution passed by the French Senate calling for sanctions on Azerbaijan, and the storm of controversy over a new BBC documentary about Azerbaijan.

entry.title: Russia ready to host new Pashinyan Aliyev meeting, Kremlin says

media:group.media:title: Russia ready to host new Pashinyan Aliyev meeting, Kremlin says
media:group.media:description:
üìçKremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said Russia is ready to host another meeting between the leaders of Armenia and Azerbaijan. üìçThe deputy prime ministers of Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Russia met in Moscow to discuss efforts to reopen transport links in the region. üìçFrench Foreign Minister Catherine Colonna called on the European Union to extend the mandate of its monitoring mission on the Armenia-Azerbaijan border. üìçFour provisions backed by Armenian American lobbying groups were axed in a compromise version of the United States‚Äô annual defense budget.
Credits: Ruptly
